comment.body: Or even make it configurable.
This sounds very interesting. Are there any apps around that use the aDTN protocol?
Thanks, mate!
PyBitmessage cannot use `keys.dat` if that file is still encrypted, so if PyBitmessage can read the file, so can an attacker.

As for other files: A password manager (say, https://www.passwordstore.org/ ) can decrypt the single password you need and write it to the console, and still keep everything encrypted. Something like that could be a solution for other files than `keys.dat`.

Encrypting your harddrive is not to protect you from the operating system (heck, you need to decrypt the filesystem for the o/s to use it), it's to protect the contents of the disk if Putin's death squad steals your harddrive.

You can just encrypt the “secret” files with gpg or similar and no spyware can get to their contents.
You need to be more specific if you want specific solutions.
ArchWiki is fan-fscking-tastic!

@Kaffie: the sweet thing is that namecoin has multiple namespaces. While the “d/” namespace is used for .bit domains, the “id/” namespace is used for, well, IDs. There are a few examples in a somewhat unrelated post: http://127.0.0.1:43110/todayilearned.bit/?Post:8

(What a pity markdown links don't work here…)
I was wondering: Since each zite has a public/private keypair, couldn't an ID be as simple as signing “something” with one of your private zeronet keys?

@Bashrc: Yes, you're right. It would definitely be good to have an ID system that works with mesh networks (and having said that, it would also be nice if Zeronet were IPv6 aware so that it could run on e.g. Hyperboria/cjdns).
Davs! :)
@Maomihz: Everybody with access to that IP address will be able to browse your Zeronet instance then. You'd better make sure your router can also hand out RFC 1918 addresses.
Haha! :)
Hang on…

You are right. Although I don't understand why, since the last transaction was on August 7, the effective balance on your account is zero and so you cannot forge.
In reality it doesn't mean anything. It would be extremely unlike that you could forge anything with the small amount of NXT on your account. For the past couple of year an account of mine that holds a considerably bigger amount of NXT has forged only some 300 NXT altogether. It generally forges around a block a day, but many blocks do not hold a transaction so no fee is paid to the forger.
Looks like a temporary glitch to me (modulus that I can't read the russian parts).
